summary: CHIKV (family Togaviridae, genus Alphavirus) causes acute febrile illness associated with severe joint pain that can persist for a long time even after viral clearance. it is regarded as a potential worldwide public health problem with no preventive or therapeutic means available. CHIKV nsP2 helicase belongs to the superfamily 1 (SF1) and shows seven conserved signature motifs which form the core of the enzyme. helicase and RNA-dependent 5′-RNA phosphatase activities have been located in the N-terminus of the protein. truncated CHIKV nsP2 (166–630 a.a. of nsP2, 465 amino acids) was expressed as a fusion protein with N-terminal Maltose-binding protein in bacterial expression system. protein was further purified by gel filtration chromatography using native buffer system. two mutants of the CHIKV nsP2 (nsP2 mut I and nsP2 mut II) were generated by site directed mutagenesis. these proteins were also expressed as MBP tagged proteins in E.coli. both proteins showed same sized bands on SDS-PAGE similar to wild type protein. CHIKV-nsP2T protein was incubated at different concentrations (5 ng to 50 ng) in a 50 l reaction containing 50 mM MOPS at pH 7.25, 1 mM ATP, 1 mM MgCl2 at 37°C for 30 min. ATPase activity of the CHIKV-nsP2T was absolutely dependent on Mg2+. CHIKV-nsP2 is just an NTPase. other possibility is that unwinding activity of CHIKV-nsP2 is dependent on protease domain. extra domains in addition to core enzyme may be necessary for conferring strand separation activity to the enzyme. yltransferase and guanylyltransferase activities required to carry out reactions have been demonstrated to be nsP1 associated. nsP2 has been identified as the RNA triphosphatase for both SFV and SINV.
